p: The time-curve of the citations referenced by scientific papers usually shows a distinct peak between 2 and 4 years after publication of the cited paper. However, many highly cited papers show the phenomenon of delayed recognition: their citation rate peaks many years after publication (Redner 2005). As the results in Table 3 show, it also needs more time to be mentioned in a policy document, because the period of origin of the policy documents is much longer than that of a typical scientific paper (see e.g. the IPCC Reports which appear only every 6–7 years, whereas a typical scientific paper arises within 1 year). This corresponds to the maximum of the difference between the percentages around 2005–2006 in the right column of Table 3.
